awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Amplifying Intelligence in Mobile Networked Systems
awd_abstract_narration:
The mobile Internet revolution is ongoing, as the technology evolves from the fourth generation (4G) to 5G and beyond, with a need to incorporate a substantially higher degree of intelligence than is present in networks today. This need is driven by the observation that current 4G systems do not provide sufficient information on network behaviors. Consequently, it poses challenges to optimize performance, diagnose failures, and dis-incentivizes deployment of new applications such as virtual and augmented realities (AR/VR), autonomous vehicles, massive Internet of things. This project seeks to enhance intelligence to the 4G/5G signaling subsystem, offering critical network control utilities, such as radio resource control and mobility management. These new designs will lead to improvements in performance and reliability to the mobile Internet infrastructure for our society. The investigator will interact closely with mobile network companies for possible technology transfer. The project will also seek to influence the upcoming 5G and beyond 5G-standardization. It will recruit and train a new generation of engineers and students, including those from groups under-represented in this area.

This project explores a novel approach of Amplifying Intelligence in Mobile networked systems (called AIM). AIM will tackle two challenges: (1) lack of knowledge at the mobile clients: The mobile operating system and application programs lack information on the underlying "black-box" network operations; (2) High complexity and lack of verification in the infrastructure: The infrastructure suffers from complex designs and operations without proper verification. AIM is a multi-disciplinary solution that applies machine learning, data science, distributed systems and computing theory to mobile networking. Through its data-driven and verifiable design, AIM offers a viable, new solution suite in four concrete technical thrusts: (T1) protocol and function analytics for data-driven clients; (T2) provable and simplified control-plane signaling for data access; (T3) enhanced error-handling design with new investigative capability of tracing; and (T4) mobile VR for data-plane signaling intelligence. This project complements the ongoing efforts on wireless access (5G New Radio) and architectural innovations (e.g., network slicing and Network Function Virtualization).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aims to make mobile networks more intelligent, thereby enhancing user experience and mobile data performance of billions of mobile users and devices over operational 5G/4G networks. We have successfully developed a transformative paradigm shift on mobile networked system research, away from the wireless-access focused efforts. Instead of upgrading wireless access and network infrastructure, this project is centered on augmenting the capabilities of learning, reasoning and reacting in standard-compliant 4G/5G network operations, particularly on learning how the network behaves, reasoning about why the network goes wrong and reacting properly if the network goes wrong.

 

We summarize our main outcomes in two aspects.

Intellectual Merit:  Our results have amplified intelligence to the 5G/4G signaling subsystem and developed new control-plane patches and functions with immediate performance and reliability enhancement in operational 5G/4G networks. As the first and leading team, we have opened up a new solution direction of data-driven smart clients. We have uncovered the problem of missed performance potentials where the actual data speed a mobile device got is much lower than what the device can get at best. We have characterized performance potentials missed in operational 4G networks in the US, developed an on-device patch solution to boosting data speed, and examined performance potentials missed in 5G networks and new mobility scenarios (say, for flying drones in the low sky). We have also leveraged the developed mobile network analytics techniques to tackle other practical problems such as reducing unnecessary radio access failures (reliability) and combating caller ID spoofing (security). On the other research front of verifiable infrastructure, our results have advanced our rigorous understanding of radio resource control and mobility management and unveiled policy conflicts and misconfigurations which have not been reported before. We have reported the first work on policy conflicts in inter-carrier roaming and dependent misconfigurations with multiple radio access used by 5G/4.5G networks. We have further developed reconfigurations to patch or fix improper configuration parameters and policies used by operational mobile networks. Our work has resulted in 19 papers most of which have been published at top networking conferences and journals including IMC’18, MobiCom’18 (x2), ToN’18, MobiCom’20 (x2), HotMobile’20, ICNP’21, MobiCom’21, INFCOM’22, IWQoS’22, INFOCOM’23 (x2), MobiCom’23, CoNext’23, HotMobile’24 (x2), IWQoS’24 and TMC’24.

Broader Impacts: Some results of this project have been reported to US carriers and involved companies, with immediate impacts on enhancing performance and user experience of thousands of millions of mobile users. Following our tradition, we have released all the datasets and artifacts used in our publications to the public. Specifically, we have released the latest version of MobileInsight v6.0 with substantial updates for 5G support (https://github.com/mobile-insight), operated an on-phone experimentation testbed MI-LAB (http://milab.cs.purdue.edu/) and released our 5G/4G measurement datasets at Github (e.g.,  recent 5G measurement datasets at https://github.com/mssn/5GMeas-Dataset). They have been used to help other research groups, companies and starts-up to conduct their own tasks, develop products and publish papers at networking conferences. Last but not the least, through curriculum development, independent studies, graduate/undergraduate advising and community outreach activities, this project helps training new workforce in 5G and next generation mobile networks.

Modified by: Chunyi Peng
